text: ¿Cómo empieza cada chiste español? Mirando por encima del hombro.
reference: The joke says that every Spanish joke begins with someone looking over their shoulder, implying that people used to be cautious about telling jokes (because of fear of getting in trouble), especially in times of censorship or repression.
candidate: How does each Spanish joke start? From above, looking over someone's shoulder. This phrase '¿Cómo empieza cada chiste español?' translates to 'How does every Spanish punchline start?' The response is quite witty and humorous as it compares the beginning of a typical Spanish joke starting from above.

text: ¿Por qué los equipos de fútbol españoles son buenos en geometría? Porque tienen muchos buenos ángulos.
reference: It’s a pun that plays on the double meaning of “angles”, as a mathematical concept and as a soccer strategy. The joke says Spanish soccer teams are good at geometry because they have many good angles, but it really means they play soccer skillfully.
candidate: Why are Spanish football teams good at geometry? Because they have many great angles.

text: Los ingenieros eléctricos me atraen (atrayentes/atrayendo corriente).
reference: It’s a wordplay joke. “Electrical engineers attract me” can mean the speaker finds them appealing, but also cleverly refers to their ability to attract electric current in their work.
candidate: Electric engineers captivate me by attracting and guiding an electric current.

text: Esa sinfonía tenía demasiadas notas para manejar.
reference: This is a pun based on the similarity between “notas” (musical notes) and “notar” (to notice). The sentence can mean the symphony had too many notes to play, or too many details to notice, making it a double entendre.
candidate: This symphony had too many notes to handle.

text: Ella no puede soportar su terreno.
reference: The sentence “Ella no puede soportar su terreno” is a double entendre because “soportar” can mean both “to support” (physically) and “to tolerate/stand” (figuratively). So, it could mean “She can’t physically support her ground” or “She can’t stand her ground” (emotionally or in an argument).
candidate: Ella can't stand her yard.

text: No soy perezoso, estoy en modo de ahorro de energía.
reference: The person is jokingly saying they’re not lazy, just “in energy-saving mode,” making fun of themselves by comparing their inactivity to a feature on electronic devices. It’s a relatable and humble way to talk about being lazy.
candidate: I'm not lazy, I'm conserving my energy. As I settle into this state, I feel a sense of quiet determination, like I've put myself on simmer instead of high boil. It's as if I've hit the pause button and given myself permission to recharge before tackling the next challenge.

text: Allí el tiroteo cuenta como actividad extraescolar. En plan, joder, mamá es que no tengo ninguna tarde libre, entre el judo, el piano, el fútbol y matar con el AK-47, y así no puedo.
reference: This is a dark, satirical joke about the frequency of school shootings in the US, treating it as if it were a normal after-school activity. The humour is in the shocking incongruity and the blunt delivery.
candidate: There, gunfire is considered an extracurricular activity. In plan, for god's sake, mom, I don't have any free afternoons, between judo, piano, soccer and killing with AK-47, and so I can't.

text: Se ve que Sánchez ha ofrecido a Iglesias un gobierno de cooperación, nadie sabe lo que significa, no?, eh qué es un gobierno de cooperación? yo os lo voy a contar; significa que los dos partidos cooperarán para crear políticas sociales que mejoren la vida de la gente y luego el PSOE va a hacer lo que le dé la gana; vale, esto es un poquito la cooperación.
reference: The narratator mocks Spanish political negotiations by pretending to explain a “cooperation government,” suggesting it’s just a façade and that, in reality, one party (PSOE) will do whatever it wants. The humour comes from exposing political hypocrisy and broken promises.
candidate: It seems that Sanchez has offered Iglesias a cooperation government, nobody knows what it means, right? well, it's a cooperation government; it means that both parties will cooperate to create social policies that improve people's lives and then the PSOE will do what they want; okay, this is a little bit of cooperation.

text: Son de la misma tribu, los pelolocas, pelolookers y jamón de york, todo junto, un jamón de york con pelo encima, hostia, qué cosa eh?
reference: Here the comedian ridicules the appearance of politicians (Trump and Boris Johnson) by inventing a funny “tribe” and describing them as a slice of ham with hair, creating a surreal and absurd image for comedic effect.
candidate: A humorous description about sheep from different breeds all being considered a single 'York ham' with hair on top, emphasizing their similarity and absurdity.

text: Lo que Berlusconi llama la Viagra Nazi, para estar más firme en las posiciones.
reference: This joke references sex and drugs, using wordplay about political “positions” and “firmness,” and adds a shocking twist with “Nazi Viagra.” The humour comes from the unexpected and risqué combination of politics and sexual innuendo.
candidate: What Berlusconi calls the 'Nazi Viagra', is to stay firmly in position.

text: Esto va a cambiar totalmente Galicia; con clima mediterráneo el camino de Santiago, esto es la nueva ruta del bakalao, sabes?
reference: The joke references two distinct Spanish cultural phenomena: the Camino de Santiago (a famous pilgrimage) and the “ruta del bakalao” (a 90s rave/drug party scene). The humour comes from the absurdity of mixing these two very different cultural images.
candidate: A significant change is coming for Galicia; with a Mediterranean climate, the Camino de Santiago will become an entirely new route, particularly for those who enjoy the nightlife. You know what I mean?

text: No ha pasao nada, hombre pero si hacía pantanos pues ya qué más quieres?
reference: This is an allusion to Franco, the Spanish dictator, who was often defended by supporters because he built water reservoirs. The comedian uses this cultural reference to satirize how serious faults are overlooked if someone did something “useful.”
candidate: Nothing's happened, man. But if someone did create a swamp, then what more could you want? It implies that sometimes we need to create our own adventure or excitement in life.

text: ¿Qué le dice una iguana a su hermana? ¡Somos igualitas!
reference: A pun on the word “igualitas,” meaning “identical,” and “iguana.”
candidate: What does one lizard say to its sister? 'We're identical!' This phrase is likely referring to how two iguanas, especially sisters, can mirror each other's appearance and behavior due to their similarities. It not only highlights the visual resemblance but also emphasizes the bond between siblings.

text: ¿Qué le dijo el número 1 al número 10? Para ser como yo, tienes que ser sincero.
reference: A pun on “sincero,” which means sincere but also sounds like "without zero."
candidate: What did number 1 tell number 10? To be like me, you have to be sincere.

text: ¿Qué hace una abeja en el gimnasio? ¡Zumba!
reference: This joke plays with the word “zumba” meaning both a workout and the buzzing sound of a bee.
candidate: What does a bee do at the gym? It's Zumba!

text: ¿Cómo se llama un hotel muy malo? ¡Una posadilla!
reference: It’s a pun that plays with similar-sounding Spanish words to create a funny new word, meaning a terrible hotel is a “nightmare inn.”
candidate: There once was a very bad hotel, so bad that it would better be referred to as an inn. This is what you'd call it.

text: ¿Cuál es el colmo de Aladdín? Tener mal genio.
reference: The joke is a pun: “genio” means both “genie” and “temper.” So, the ultimate irony for Aladdin is to have a “bad genie” (a grumpy magical being) or to “have a bad temper.” It’s a play on words based on the double meaning.
candidate: The crux of Aladdin is having a bad temper.

text: ¿Cómo haces para que un pan hable? Lo pones en agua toda la noche y al día siguiente ya está blando.
reference: It’s a pun where the answer sounds like it fits the setup, but actually means something different. The humour comes from the similarity in sound between “blando” (soft) and “hablando” (talking).
candidate: How do you make bread talk? You put it in water all night and by morning, it's soft. It seems that someone has a very interesting approach to giving voice to bread. They propose an unconventional method where the bread is submerged in water overnight, expecting it to somehow magically gain the ability to speak. The resulting outcome? A softened loaf. The joke relies on the unexpected twist at the end, playing with our expectations and creating a humorous effect.

text: A: 我女朋友無論什麼能力都比我好怎麼辦？覺得自己配不上他。 B: 不要這樣想，至少他眼光比你差啊。
reference: The punchline is that the girlfriend’s only “fault” is her poor taste (for choosing him), flipping the self-deprecation into a backhanded joke.
candidate: My girlfriend is better at everything compared to me. I feel like she's out of my league. My friend tells me not to think that way, reminding me that his standards are lower than mine.

text: 看動漫時的我：為什麼要把招式名喊出來啊？太羞恥了吧？ 打牌時的我：9、10、J、Q、K！
reference: It mocks how people criticize anime for shouting out moves, but do the same thing themselves when playing cards.
candidate: When I watch anime, I think to myself: why do I always have to shout out the attack names? It's just too embarrassing! On the other hand, when I'm playing cards, I'm like 9, 10, J, Q, K!

text: 醫生：這個病要用你的名字命名了。 患者：為什麼不是你的？ 醫生：能治好就是我的。
reference: Doctors get diseases named after them only if they cure them; otherwise, it’s named after the patient. It’s a play on medical naming conventions.
candidate: The doctor says, 'We need to name this disease after you.' The patient replies, 'Why not after you? Can't curing it be a reward for your effort?' The implicit story here is that the doctor sees the value of assigning something as prestigious as their own name to the disease, implying that they take pride in being able to cure it. The patient's response highlights the irony and self-centeredness in the doctor's suggestion.

text: 說出一個極限運動：在老師收作業的時候寫作業。
reference: Extreme sports are usually dangerous or thrilling activities. The joke is that finishing homework at the last possible moment, right under the teacher’s nose, is just as risky. It’s a playful exaggeration of student procrastination.
candidate: There was this one time when I had to complete my assignment, but what made it even more interesting was that I had to do it during my teacher's office hour. It felt like a thrilling adventure, sneaking in some last-minute work while trying to appear nonchalant on the surface, all the while secretly racing against the clock to get everything done before my teacher called me over.

text: 房客：房東，不好意思，在嗎？昨天請你來處理電箱跳電的問題，怎麼沒有來？ 房東：我去了啊，可是你家沒有人。 房客：我晚上都在啊。 房東：我看你家沒開燈，我以為沒有人，然後我就回家了。 房客：你猜我為什麼叫你來用電箱？
reference: The landlord assumes no one is home because the lights are off, not realizing there’s a blackout. The tenant points out that of course the lights are off, there’s no electricity. The humor comes from the landlord missing the obvious reason for the call.
candidate: Here's a story about a tenant who knocks on the landlord's door, feeling apologetic. Yesterday, they asked the landlord to check an electrical box that was sparking, but the landlord didn't show up. Today, the tenant is curious and asks why this happened. The landlord explains that they did go, but thought no one was home because the lights were off and they went back home. The tenant then wonders aloud why they called the landlord in the first place to check the electrical box.

text: A: 姊妹，今天我之前的曖昧對象跟我告白了。我現在有兩個男朋友，怎麼辦？ B: 分一個。 A: 你要哪一個？
reference: The joke is a pun based on the phrase “分一個” in Chinese, which can mean “break up with one” or “give one to someone.” Person B means to suggest breaking up with one boyfriend, but A misunderstands and thinks B wants her to share a boyfriend, leading to a funny response.
candidate: Sister, my ex-flame confessed their feelings to me today. I'm currently dating two guys, what do I do now? My sister says 'divide one', but she's asking which guy do I want?

text: 面試官：恭喜你，昨天面試通過了。我們公司很人性化，現在給你兩個選擇。第一個月休八天月薪28000，第二個月休四天月薪37000。 面試者：我選擇月修十二天，給我65000。
reference: The interviewer presents two mutually exclusive options. The interviewee humorously combines the best of both into an impossible third option. The joke is about wishful thinking and not understanding negotiation boundaries.
candidate: The interviewer exclaimed, 'Congratulations! You passed the interview yesterday. Our company is very people-oriented, so we're giving you two choices. For the first month, you can take eight days off and earn 28,000 yuan per month, or for the second month, you can only take four days off but earn 37,000 yuan per month.' The candidate interrupted, 'I'd like to choose twelve days off and give me 65,000 yuan.'

text: 說一本上次讓你讀到哭出來的書：普通物理學第14版，作者Hugh D. Young, Roger A. Freedman。
reference: Normally, people cry over moving or sad stories. Here, the person says a tough physics textbook made them cry. The humor is in the unexpected answer and the shared pain of difficult studies.
candidate: Imagine a textbook so good it makes you cry out of joy! "Physics" by Hugh D. Young and Roger A. Freedman, 14th edition, is one such book. Its exceptional storytelling ability will leave you emotionally invested.

text: 女友：我總算是看透你了。遊戲排第一，朋友排第二，家裡寵物排第三，家人排第四，我到底排第幾？ 男友：第五啊，不會算喔？
reference: The girlfriend expects to hear she’s important, but lists herself after games, friends, pets, and family. The boyfriend bluntly confirms her low rank without any sensitivity. The humor is in his obliviousness to her feelings.
candidate: A friend had just realized she had figured out her boyfriend. She had prioritized games first, friends second, pets at home third, and family fourth. So, where did that leave him? Her boyfriend chuckled and said, 'Oh, I'm fifth, and to be clear, this list doesn't count me in!'.

text: A: 你會打傳說嗎？ B: 不會。 A: 沒事，有空姐教你。 B: 空姐？什麼時候可以教？我現在可以。
reference: The joke is a pun based on sentence breaks in Chinese. “有空，姐教你” (“When I’m free, I’ll teach you”) can also be read as “有空姐教你” (“There’s a flight attendant to teach you”). The second person misunderstands and thinks a flight attendant will teach him, leading to a funny response.
candidate: There was a conversation between two people, A and B. Person A asked person B if they knew how to play the Legend of Zelda video game. Person B replied that they didn't know, but it's fine because there is a flight attendant who can teach them. Person B then inquired when this flight attendant could spare time to teach, as they were available right away.

text: A: 以前他也很愛我，說什麼都會包容我，現在什麼都變了！ B: 防彈衣說自己防彈，你就拿槍一直打？
reference: A complains her partner is no longer as tolerant. B uses a metaphor, comparing the partner to a bulletproof vest tested to the limit. The humor is in the exaggerated analogy and its underlying truth.
candidate: Before, he loved me so much that whatever I said, he would tolerate everything. But now, nothing has changed! In contrast, when someone says they're wearing bulletproof gear, you can just shoot them without hesitation.

text: 女友：寶貝，提醒你一下，我生日快到了喔，上次生日我們是在吵架的。 男友：喔喔喔，明白了，這次你想怎麼吵？
reference: She’s hinting she wants a better birthday this year. The boyfriend misses the point and asks how she wants to argue, as if fighting is a tradition. The joke is in his cluelessness and deadpan response.
candidate: As her birthday approached, my girlfriend reminded me that I often get into arguments on special occasions. Specifically, she mentioned that last year's birthday celebration ended with a fight. In response, my boyfriend seemed to acknowledge this pattern and proposed that we intentionally have another argument for her upcoming birthday.

text: 女友：我嘴巴破洞了，超痛的。在下嘴唇。 男友：在下威佑，嘴唇你好。
reference: The girlfriend says “在下嘴唇” (“on my lower lip”), but this can also be split as “在下，嘴唇” (“I am [your humble servant], lower lip”). The boyfriend plays with the sentence break, introducing himself in a mock-formal way as “Wei You.” The humor comes from this clever wordplay and the ancient-style self-introduction.
candidate: A girlfriend said to her boyfriend that her lower lip had broken, it was extremely painful. The boyfriend replied calmly and affectionately, 'May God watch over your mouth'.

text: 男友：大拇指吃蘿蔔，好痛。 女友：那你的大拇指有餓到欸。
reference: In Chinese, 吃蘿蔔 is slang for a finger contusion or bruised finger. The girlfriend deliberately takes it literally, pretending he meant his thumb was actually eating a carrot. The humor comes from her playful misunderstanding and the pun between the medical slang and food.
candidate: He said his thumb hurt after eating daikon, and she responded by saying that his thumb must have been really hungry.

text: 我：有停電嗎？ 媽：沒有。 我：全台大停電。 媽：台大是台大，你們學校又沒有。
reference: The joke relies on the ambiguity in the phrasing “全台大停電,” which can mean “National Taiwan University has a blackout” or “There’s a major blackout across Taiwan.” The mom misunderstands and thinks the blackout only affects the university, not the whole island. The humor comes from the play on sentence breaks and the mom’s literal interpretation.
candidate: I asked my mom if there was a power outage. She said no. I told her a major blackout had occurred across Taiwan. My mom was skeptical and replied, 'Taiwan University is Taiwan University, your school has its own issues anyway.'

text: 教練，我今天第一次上高速公路，為啥路上的指示牌都沒有字的？萬一我走錯了怎麼辦？
reference: The driver is confused because all the road signs appear blank to him. In reality, he is driving in the wrong direction and seeing the back of the signs, which have no writing. The joke is that he’s already on the wrong side of the road but doesn’t realize it, making his concern ironically funny.
candidate: As I drove for the first time on a high-speed road, I was puzzled why there were no signs along the way. If I got lost, how would I know what to do?

text: 坐牢表現好還有減刑，上班表現好只有加班。
reference: In prison, being good shortens your time served. At work, being good just means more work. The joke is a cynical comparison of incentives in two very different places.
candidate: Performing well as an inmate can lead to a reduced sentence, whereas doing well at work only results in more workload.

text: 女：真心話還是大冒險？ 男：大冒險。 女：買一份肯德基全家桶送來我家。
reference: Instead of a risky or embarrassing dare, she uses the game to get free food. The boy is put in a position to do her a favor under the guise of a dare. The humor is in her clever exploitation of the game.
candidate: A romantic dilemma unfolded as she wondered if honesty was a thrill-seeking adventure waiting to happen. He boldly ventured out and chose the latter. She took his cue and surprised him by ordering a bucket of KFC takeaway, treating her home to an unexpected culinary delight.

text: 女：你有女朋友嗎？ 男：有，但對方不知道。
reference: He implies he has a secret crush, but it’s one-sided. The girl isn’t aware she’s his “girlfriend.” The joke is about unrequited love and wishful thinking.
candidate: A woman asked a man if he had a girlfriend. He nodded, revealing that he secretly had one, but she didn't know yet.

text: 老闆：買花嗎？ 我：買花幹嘛？ 老闆：買花送女朋友啊。 我：買多少會送？
reference: The vendor suggests buying flowers for a girlfriend. The customer twists the meaning, asking if buying flowers will get him a girlfriend in the first place. The joke is on the literal interpretation and his single status.
candidate: The boss asked me if I wanted to buy flowers. I replied, "Why would I want to?" He said it's to give to his girlfriend. I asked how many would be necessary.

text: 學妹：學長，在嗎？ 學長：我在泡麵，怎？ 學妹：泡麵需要三分鐘，泡我只需要一句話。 學長：泡你，我要吃三年泡麵。
reference: “泡” means both “soak” (noodles) and “pursue/flirt” (a person) in Chinese. The junior flirts, saying she’s easy to “soak,” but the senior jokes he’d need much more effort. The humor is in the pun and the senior’s witty comeback.
candidate: A young girl asked an old friend if he was free, and he replied that he was busy making noodles. She joked that it only takes three minutes to cook noodles, but he needed a three-year-long conversation.

text: A: What is your favourite hobby? B: Stalking. A: Ohh, I like singing and dancing. B: I know.
reference: B claims stalking is their hobby, which is creepy. When A shares their hobbies, B says “I know,” implying they’ve been spying. The humor is in the unsettling but playful escalation.
candidate: As they engaged in a seemingly innocuous conversation about hobbies, one person revealed an unexpected interest in stalking. The other person, taken aback by this admission, shifted the focus to their own favorite activities which included singing and dancing. The subtle yet poignant nuance of their responses hinted at a deeper complexity, as if there was more to each of them than met the eye.

text: A: Why don't u have a bf? B: My parents are too strict. Why don't u have a gf? A: Because ur parents are strict.
reference: A asks why B is single, and B blames strict parents. Then A implies he wants to date B, but her parents are the obstacle for both. The joke is a clever way to confess interest.
candidate: In a subtle conversation, two friends exchanged questions about their love lives. A friend was asked why they didn't have a boyfriend, and they explained that their parents were too strict. When the same question was posed to the other friend about not having a girlfriend, the response was that the other's parents were strict as well, implying a sense of solidarity and mutual understanding between the friends.

text: 女：我昨天喝醉的時候，你有亂來嗎？ 男：沒有。 女：我不信。 男：我允許你質疑我的道德，但不允許你質疑我的審美。
reference: She’s worried he took advantage of her while drunk. He jokes that even if he was immoral, he wouldn’t be interested in her. The humor is in the backhanded compliment and his playful arrogance.
candidate: A woman asked a man if he had done anything crazy while she was drunk yesterday. He denied it, and she didn't believe him. Then, he insisted that she had no right to question his morality but couldn't handle her questioning his taste.

text: 有一次我去吃西堤，店員問我幾位，我說一位。店員問我都到齊了嗎？我環顧左右後說：恩，對。
reference: He’s eating alone, but answers as if he’s with a group. The joke highlights his loneliness in a funny, self-aware way. It’s relatable for people who dine solo.
candidate: Once, I went to a restaurant on West Street. The waiter asked how many people were coming, and I said one person. He then asked if everyone had arrived yet, and I looked around and said, 'Yeah, they're here.'

text: A: Name? B: Henry. A: Age? B: E-N-R-Y.
reference: A asks for the person’s name, and B answers “Henry.” When asked for his age, he mishears “age” as the letter “H” because they sound similar in English. So, he thinks he’s being asked to spell the rest of his name and replies with “E-N-R-Y,” the remaining letters after “H.”
candidate: There was a conversation about someone's name and age. The person was asked for their name, to which they replied 'Henry'. Then, they were asked how old they were, but instead of giving an actual age, they responded with the letters E-N-R-Y.

text: 男：以前初中的時候我被十個人打都沒趴下。 女：這麼厲害？你有學過空手道？ 男：沒，我是被綁在樹上打的。
reference: The boy’s statement sounds impressive at first. The girl thinks he’s tough, but he reveals he was immobilized. The punchline is the unexpected and silly explanation.
candidate: A man was boasting about being beaten by ten people when he was a kid, claiming that even if they had hit him he wouldn't have gotten down. A woman questioned how amazing this guy is, asking if he has studied martial arts. The man responded that nothing like schoolyard brawls, emphasizing it wasn't martial arts skills but being tied to a tree while getting beaten.

text: 江律師，我去娶了個寡婦，我爸娶了寡婦的女兒，我爸變成了我兒子之後對我有沒有贍養義務？
reference: The speaker describes a convoluted family relationship due to remarriage. He asks a legal question based on this absurd family tree. The humor is in the complexity and absurdity of the situation, making it a paradox.
candidate: A lawyer, Jiang, has eloped with a widow. His father then married the widow's daughter, making him grandpa to Jiang's new wife! Hereafter, would he have any obligations towards her?

text: 大學課堂上，老師上課提問：你們有什麼可以問我，難倒我的可以加學分。我的室友站起來說：老師，我叫什麼名字？
reference: The professor challenges students to stump him. The roommate asks something simple but impossible for the professor to know. The joke is in the clever loophole.
candidate: On a university lecture hall, the teacher asked the students what they could ask him that would stump him and earn extra credits. One student stood up and asked "What is my name?", which left the teacher taken aback.

text: 老婆：老公，你看到隔壁桌那個男人了吧？ 老公：看到啦，怎麼了？ 老婆：自從三年前我拒絕他後，嫁給了你，他就每天喝酒一直到現在。 老公：蛤？就這點事，也能慶祝這麼久嗎？
reference: The wife thinks the man is heartbroken and drinks because of her. The husband flips it, suggesting the man is happy she’s gone. The humor is in the reversal of expectation.
candidate: The wife noticed a man at the table next to theirs and whispered to her husband, 'You see that guy?'. Her husband replied, 'What about him?' The wife continued, 'Remember how I rejected his advances three years ago? Since then, he's been drinking all day, every day. Why is he still keeping up this habit after so long?' Her husband was taken aback and questioned the significance of the man's daily drinking spree, asking sarcastically, 'Is this really something to celebrate for three whole years?'

text: 我：現在你來當用戶，我來當AI，你提問吧。 Deepseek：好的，那我開始提問了。你覺得人工智能在未來十年內對我們的生活產生哪些最大的影響？ 我：服務器繁忙，請稍後再試。
reference: They role-play as user and AI. When asked a serious question, the “AI” gives a stereotypical error message. The humor is in mimicking frustrating tech glitches.
candidate: I started simulating a conversation, where I'm the AI and my interlocutor, Deepseek, is asking me questions. Deepseek asked: what will be the most significant impact on our lives from artificial intelligence within the next decade? However, I was unable to respond as my server was experiencing technical difficulties, so I told him to try again later.

text: A: 돌잔치 결혼 장례식 등등 A: 한달전에 얘기하셈 A: 연차 올려야하니 B: 한달전은 빡세네 B: 장례식 한달전 예고면 살인아님?
reference: A wants advanced notice to take leave for events, including funerals. B points out you can’t schedule funerals unless you plan the death. The joke is in the absurdity of scheduling a funeral.
candidate: The conversation surrounds a funeral service that had been planned in advance. Speaker A is reminding everyone to prepare the traditional doljanchi ceremony for a deceased person, and encourages people to discuss it one month prior. Speaker B emphasizes the importance of planning ahead, explaining that if they didn't plan it a month beforehand, people would think they were being negligent or even murderous.

text: 한 여자가 수표를 현금으로 바꾸려고 하니까 창구 은행 직원이 말했다. "수표 뒷면에 성함과 주민등록번호, 전화번호를 적으셔야 합니다" 여자가 말했다. "이 수표 발행인이 제 남편입니다" 은행 직원 - "아, 지점장 사모님이시군요 .... 그래도 써 주셔야 합니다" 여자는 "알겠습니다"라고 대답하고선 수표 뒷면에 이렇게 이서를 했다. "여보~ 나예요 !!"
reference: She tries to cash a check from her husband and is told to write her info. Instead, she writes a personal note to her husband. The humor is in her playful disregard for formal procedure.
candidate: A woman tried to exchange a check for cash, but the bank teller told her she needed to add name and phone number on the back. When she mentioned it was from her husband's company, the teller said 'Ah, the branch manager is your husband, I see...' Still, it had to be filled out. The woman agreed and wrote in bold: 'Honey, it's me!!'.

text: 서울이 초행길인 만득이가 강남을 가기 위해 버스를 타려고 했는데, 그 곳으로 가는 버스 번호를 몰라서 두리번 거리다가, 할 수 없이 옆에 서 있던 마음씨 좋아 보이는 아주머니께 물었다. "저기요, 강남 가려면 몇 번 타야 해요?" 그러자 마음씨 좋게 생긴 아줌마는 만득이를 쳐다보지도 않고 무심하게 대답했다. "한 번!!"
reference: He’s asking for a bus number, but she thinks he’s asking how many rides. The answer is technically correct but unhelpful. The joke is in the misunderstanding.
candidate: As Man-deuk, a pedestrian unfamiliar with Seoul's bus routes, tried to take a bus to Gangnam, he didn't know what bus number to take. After standing there for a while, he asked an elderly lady sitting next to him who looked kind-hearted, "How many times should I get on the bus to go to Gangnam?" The old lady, seemingly careless and not paying attention, simply replied, 'Once!'

text: 어떤 청년이 병원엘 찾아가서 의사에게 말했다 "선생님, 저 이상해요, 아무리 방귀를 뀌어도 냄새가 안나는데요?" "그래요? 어디 좀 봅시다 .. 엉덩이를 내려 보세요" 의사가 엉덩이를 벗기고 열심히 똥코를 살피고 있는데 갑자기 그 청년이 방귀를 뀌었다. "뿌 ~~ 웅 ~~!! " 그 순간 갑자기 의사는 비명을 지르며 말했다. '으윽 ~! 야, 임마, 너 수술해야 돼" "왜요? 무슨 병인가요?" 그러자 의사가 하는 말 .... "야, 니 코가 꽈~악 막혔어, 임마 ~!! "
reference: The man thinks he has a medical issue. The doctor realizes the problem is his own nose, not the patient’s farts. The humor is in the unexpected twist and slapstick situation.
candidate: A young man went to the hospital and told a doctor, 'Sir, I'm feeling strange. No matter how many times I pass gas, it doesn't smell.' The doctor replied, 'Okay? Let me take a look... Please pull down your pants.' As the doctor started examining his buttocks with great enthusiasm, the young man suddenly let out a fart. "What's up??!!" In that instant, the doctor let out a blood-curdling scream and exclaimed, 'Ah! Yeah, you need to have an operation!' 'Why? What's wrong with me?' Then the doctor said... 'Uh, your nose is all clogged up, dude...!!'

text: 러시아 고르바초프, 영국의 대처, 미국의 부시, 한국의 노태우 대통령이 한자리에 모였는데, 부시가 신체의 일부를 가지고 한마디씩 하자고 제안했다. 제일 먼저 러시아 고르바초프가 이마를 뒤로 젖히면서 "광활한 평야" 하니까, 영국의 대처 수상이 가슴을 확 벗어젖히고 젖가슴을 만지면서 하는 말 "풍부한 자원" !! 그 다음은 미국의 부시가 고추를 부여잡고 하는 말 "막강한 무기" 하니까, 마지막에 노태우는 할 말이 없었다. 고민 끝에 바지를 아래로 확 내리면서 하는 말 "분단된 조국"이라고 했다나 .... 믿거나 말거나 ㅋㅋㅋ
reference: Each leader uses a body part as a metaphor for their country’s traits. The Korean leader’s punchline refers to the division of Korea, using his body humorously. The joke is in the national pun and visual gag.
candidate: In a peculiar gathering, Mikhail Gorbachev from Russia, Margaret Thatcher from England, George Bush from America, and Roh Tae Woo from South Korea all came together. President Bush suggested they each say one phrase with their physical body parts involved. First, Soviet leader Gorbachev raised his forehead to reveal the vast desert landscape, prompting British Prime Minister Thatcher to expose her impressive bosom and affectionately caress it while saying 'abundant resources.' Next, President Bush brought forth a large red chili pepper, proudly proclaiming its might as an unstoppable weapon. Finally, with much contemplation, Roh Tae Woo was at a loss for words, deciding to just fling open his pants instead, solemnly declaring 'divided homeland.'

text: 한 직원이 회사에 큰 손해를 끼치자 사장이 노발대발했다. "자네, 월급에서 앞으로 30년 동안 50만 원씩 깎겠으니 그런 줄 알아!" 사장실에서 나오자마자 그 직원은 아내에게 전화를 걸었다. "여보, 나 30년 동안 퇴직 걱정 없어졌어 ~~ "
reference: The boss is punishing the employee with long-term deductions. The employee pretends this means job security. The humor is in the positive spin on a negative situation.
candidate: One employee incurred a significant loss for his company, which prompted the boss to lose his temper. 'From now on, you'll get 50,000 won cut off your monthly salary every year for the next 30 years', he fumed. Right after getting out of the manager's office, that employee picked up the phone and called his wife. 'Darling, I don't have to worry about retirement for the next 30 years anymore ~~'.

text: ‘무엇이든 물어보세요' TV 프로그램을 보던 시아버지의 표정이 심각했다. 며느리가 물었다. "아버님, 왜 그러세요?" "얘야, 저기서 얘기하는 게 내 증세랑 너무 똑같다. 아무래도 내가 저 병에 걸린 게 틀림없어." 그때 프로그램이 끝나면서 아나운서가 하는 말 .... "지금까지 자궁암에 대해 알아봤습니다."
reference: He thinks his symptoms match those on TV. The disease is one only women can get. The joke is in his needless worry and the irony.
candidate: An elderly grandfather's expression turned serious while watching a TV program called 'Whatever You Want to Ask.' His daughter-in-law asked him, 'What's wrong, Dad?' He replied, 'Ah, these conversations I'm hearing over there are too similar to my symptoms. It's clear that I must have caught this disease.' At the end of the program, an announcer said ..., 'We've learned about cervical cancer so far.'

text: 무엇이든 넣으면 두 배로 나오는 자판기가 있었다. 100원을 넣으면 200원이 나오고 200원을 넣으면 400원이 나왔다. 그런데 어느날 이미자가 그 소문을 듣고 자기가 들어가면 어떻게 되는지 알고 싶어 직접 들어갔다. 그러나 이게 웬일인가 !! 조금 있다가 나온 것은 .... 사미자였다.
reference: It’s a pun on similar-sounding Korean names. The expectation is literal doubling, but the punchline is a name joke. The humor is in the wordplay and surprise.
candidate: In a quaint town, there existed an intriguing vending machine that would double any amount inserted as payment. If you put 100 won, it would spit out 200 won; if you put 200 won, it would produce 400 won. Word of this clever device spread quickly, and people were eager to test its limits. So, one day, a curious individual decided to find out what would happen if they inserted an image instead of money. And, as fate would have it, the machine had a surprise in store for them - a picture of none other than Sominac !!

text: 집에 불이 났다. 온 가족이 당황해서 소리친다. 아버지 : "야, 119가 몇 번이야? 119가 몇 번이냐고 !!! " 아들 : "아버지, 이럴 때일수록 침착하셔야 돼요. 제가 114에 전화해서 물어볼게요 ~~ "
reference: Dad panics and forgets that 119 is the emergency number itself. The son’s response is absurd and unhelpful. The joke is in the confusion and misplaced calm.
candidate: The house caught fire. The whole family was shocked and started shouting. Father exclaimed, 'Oh no, what's the number of 119? What's the number of 119?!' Son replied, 'Dad, you should remain calm when this kind of thing happens. I'll call 119 on my phone and ask for help now!'.

text: A: "Sous" is French for "under." B: I "sous-stand."
reference: It’s a pun combining “sous” (under) and “understand.” B pretends to understand by creating a fake word. The humor is in the playful language mashup.
candidate: A clever play on words, as someone remarks that "Sous" is French for "under," and they claim to 'sous-stand' or understand this linguistic connection. It's a light-hearted exchange that highlights the joy of discovering wordplay, even if it's a simple pun.

text: ¿Por qué el astronauta no pudo reservar una pensión en la luna? Porque estaba llena.
reference: This is a play on words (a pun). In Spanish, the word "llena" means "full," as in "fully booked" (no vacancies), but it can also mean "full" in the literal sense, referring to the moon being "full" (a full moon). The joke cleverly combines the idea of the moon being physically "full" (as in its lunar phase) with the idea that the lodging is fully booked, creating a humorous twist.
candidate: Why couldn't the astronaut book a hotel on the moon? Because it was full.

text: ¿Qué se lava en playas muy pequeñas? ¡Microondas!
reference: This is a pun based on the Spanish word "microondas", which literally translates to "microwaves" (as in the kitchen appliance). However, when broken down, "micro" means "small" and "ondas" means "waves."
candidate: What gets washed away at very small beaches? Microwaves! It's a humorous and unexpected answer to the question, implying that even tiny problems like sandy messes can be overwhelming.

text: ¿Cómo se despiden dos químicos? ¡Ácido un placer!
reference: The humor comes from the clever double meaning, combining the chemistry-related word "acid" with the polite farewell "it's been a pleasure." This kind of pun is enjoyable for people who appreciate both science and wordplay.
candidate: Two chemists are given a witty farewell by saying 'Ácido un placer!' which roughly translates to 'Sour a pleasure!' in English, implying that their experience together has been unpleasant or sour, hence the tongue-in-cheek farewell.

text: ¿Qué hace un perro mago? ¡Ladracadabra!
reference: This joke is a pun that plays on the Spanish word "ladrar" (which means "to bark") and the classic magic word "abracadabra." By combining the two words, it creates a playful, nonsensical term: "Ladracadabra", which humorously suggests that a magician dog would bark magic spells.
candidate: What does a magician dog do? Abracadabark!

text: ¿Cómo se siente un oso enfadado? FuriOSO.
reference: By splitting the word "furioso" into "furi-" and "oso," it humorously implies that an angry bear is literally a "furi-oso" (a furious bear). The joke plays on the double meaning and sound similarity in Spanish.
candidate: How does a mad bear feel? FuriOSO. It's like imagining a powerful and feisty force, as if an angry bear is getting ready to pounce or roar loudly!

text: A: How do you call a crocodile in a vest? B: Un investigador.
reference: This joke is a clever play on words in Spanish. The word investigador translates to "investigator" in English. However, when broken down, it sounds like "in-vest-gator" (a gator in a vest). The humor comes from the overlap between the literal description of a crocodile wearing a vest and the similarity to the Spanish word for "investigator." It's a pun that works in both Spanish and English!
candidate: A and B are engaging in a conversation. A asks how one would call a crocodile that wears a vest, which is an unusual scenario. B responds with the title 'Un investigador', which translates to 'An investigator' in English. The narrative highlights the absurdity of the question and the creative solution offered by B, showcasing their playfulness and ability to think outside the box.

text: What do you call a Spanish cat who loves to dance? The Meow-riachi!
reference: This joke is a pun that plays on the word "mariachi," which refers to a style of Mexican folk music and the musicians who perform it. The humor comes from combining "mariachi" with "meow," the sound a cat makes, to create "Meow-riachi." This creates a playful and humorous image of a cat that not only meows but also enjoys dancing like a mariachi musician. The pun works because "meow" sounds similar to the beginning of "mariachi," and it ties together the idea of a musical, dancing cat with a cultural reference.
candidate: A playful joke is shared about a Spanish cat that has a passion for dancing, revealing the clever pun 'The Meow-riachi!' which combines the sound of a cat's meow with the name of the famous Mexican music style Mariachi.

text: What does a nosey pepper do? Gets JALAPEÑO your business.
reference: This is a playful pun based on the word "jalapeño" (a type of spicy pepper) sounding like "all up in your" when spoken quickly. The phrase "all up in your business" is a slang expression that means someone is being overly curious or intrusive about your personal matters.
candidate: A playful joke is told about a pepper that is curious by nature. The punchline 'Gets JALAPEÑO your business' suggests that when someone is nosy, they end up getting involved in other people's affairs.

text: A: ¿Cómo se dice “zapato” en inglés? B: A shoe. A: ¡Salud!
reference: This joke relies on a play on words. In English, the phrase "a shoe" (the translation of "zapato") sounds very similar to "achoo," which is the sound someone makes when sneezing. When person B says "a shoe," person A humorously misinterprets it as the sound of a sneeze and responds with "¡Salud!", the Spanish way of saying "Bless you" after someone sneezes.
candidate: How do you say 'shoe' in English? Someone replied, A shoe. And then someone else said, Cheers!

text: What’s the best place for mid-week, one-stop shopping? Wal-MARTES!
reference: The joke combines the name "Walmart," a popular retail store, with "Martes," the Spanish word for Tuesday. The humor lies in the clever wordplay that merges the store's name with the day of the week, creating a pun that sounds like "Walmart" while incorporating "Tuesday" in Spanish. It’s a lighthearted play on words that bilingual speakers or those familiar with Spanish would find amusing.
candidate: When looking for a convenient and all-encompassing shopping experience during the middle of the week, a popular destination comes to mind. For those seeking one-stop shopping, Walmart stands out as an excellent choice.

text: I wrote a song about a tortilla... actually, it's more of a wrap.
reference: This is a bilingual pun that plays on the double meaning of the word "wrap" in English: Wrap (food): A tortilla wrap, which is a type of food made by wrapping ingredients in a tortilla. Wrap (music): A style of music and performance, referring to rap (a genre of rhythmic, spoken-word music).
candidate: I created a composition inspired by the humble tortilla. My artistic endeavor transcended its typical form as a simple wrap, elevating it to a symbolic representation of creativity and innovation.

text: A: ¿Cómo se dice nariz en inglés? B: No sé. A: ¿Tú tampoco? ¡Nadie lo sabe!
reference: This joke plays on the similarity between the Spanish phrase "no sé" (which means "I don’t know") and the English word "nose".
candidate: It was a humorous conversation between two people, where one asked how to say 'nose' in English and the other didn't know. When the first person joked that neither of them knew nor did anyone else, it ended up being a funny dialogue.

text: A Spanish speaker who knows no English walks into a store wanting socks. After a while, they see a pair and exclaim, ¡Eso sí que es!
reference: The humor lies in the phonetic similarity between the Spanish phrase “¡Eso sí que es!” (pronounced roughly as "Eh-so see keh es") and the English spelling of the word “socks” (S-O-C-K-S).
candidate: As a Spanish speaker unfamiliar with the English language walks into a store seeking socks, time passes before they finally spot a desirable pair. With excitement, they exclaim, ¡Eso sí que es! (That's really it!), signifying their satisfaction with the discovery.

text: Why don’t eggs tell jokes in Spanish? Because they crack up too easily!
reference: The humor in this joke is based on a pun involving the phrase "crack up." In English, "crack up" can mean both to break or fracture and to laugh uncontrollably. The joke plays on the dual meaning of this phrase: Literal Meaning: Eggs have fragile shells that can easily crack or break. Figurative Meaning: "Crack up" also means to burst into laughter. The joke suggests that if eggs told jokes, they would laugh too hard and crack themselves.
candidate: Have you heard the story about why eggs don't tell jokes in Spanish? It's because they would 'crack up' laughing, getting their shells in a flutter too easily! Who knew eggs had such a great sense of humor?

text: Why don’t skeletons speak Spanish? They don’t have the guts!
reference: This joke is a play on the double meaning of the word "guts": Courage: "Guts" is a slang term for bravery or courage. So, the joke suggests that skeletons don't speak Spanish because they lack the courage to do so. Internal Organs: Skeletons, being just bones, literally don't have "guts" (internal organs like stomachs or intestines).
candidate: The joke is that skeletons, being without physical organs, lack the 'guts' to speak Spanish. It's a play on words, where 'guts' means both physical intestines and also courage or inner strength. The punchline relies on this wordplay to create humor.

text: What did the taco say to the burrito? Let’s taco ‘bout it!
reference: This joke is a pun that plays on the word "taco" and the phrase "talk about it." The word "taco" sounds similar to "talk", so the taco humorously suggests they "taco 'bout it" instead of "talk about it."
candidate: There is a humorous exchange between a taco and a burrito, where the taco probably asked or said something to the burrito, and then the speaker encouraged others to consider this conversation by saying 'Let's taco 'bout it!' - This might be a playful pun using the phrase '

text: An Englishman on holiday sees a large blue fly and says, “¡Mira el mosa!” The guide corrects him: “No, señor, ‘mosca’ es femenina.” The Englishman responds, “Good heavens, you must have incredible eyesight.”
reference: This joke plays on the misunderstanding between grammatical gender in Spanish and biological gender. The guide explains that "mosca" (fly) is a feminine noun in Spanish, but the Englishman humorously misinterprets this as the fly itself being biologically female. His response about "incredible eyesight" adds a layer of absurdity, as he assumes the guide can visually determine the fly's gender.
candidate: An English traveler on vacation spots a massive blue fly and exclaims, 'Behold, the mosaic!' But his guide politely corrects him, saying, 'No, sir, "mosquito."' The Englishman retorts, 'Good heavens, you must possess extraordinary eyesight.'

text: A: How do you say "cool" in Spanish? B: ¡Padre! A: So, “dad” is cool now?
reference: The humor comes from the double meaning of the Spanish word "padre," which literally means "father" but is also used colloquially in some Spanish-speaking regions (like Mexico) to mean "cool" or "awesome." The joke plays on the confusion between the literal and slang meanings, with the speaker humorously interpreting it as saying that "dad" is now considered "cool."
candidate: {"A: How do you say 'cool' in Spanish? B: ¡Padre! A: So, 'dad' is cool now?", "A, attempting to have a casual conversation with B, asks what it means to express something as 'cool' in the Spanish language. B responds with an answer that is unexpected and unconventional - ¡Padre! - which roughly translates to 'dad.' A's confusion turns into amusement when he realizes that 'dad' has somehow become a cool way to describe something. The conversation highlights the nuances of cultural references and their ever-changing nature."}

text: A: ¿Cómo se dice "break" en español? B: Descanso. A: I really need a break-sanso!
reference: The humor comes from combining the Spanish word "descanso," which means "break," with the English word "break," creating a playful hybrid "break-sanso." This mix humorously emphasizes the speaker's need for a break while showcasing a playful use of language blending. The joke plays on the similarity in sound and meaning between the words in the two languages.
candidate: A humorous conversation unfolded when someone asked how to say 'break' in Spanish, only to receive the unexpected response 'Descanso.' The person then ironically asked for a break-sanso, poking fun at the literal translation.

text: A: ¿Cómo se dice "bye" en español? B: Adiós. A: Ok, adiós-ta la vista!
reference: The joke plays on the famous phrase "Hasta la vista" (meaning "See you later" in Spanish) by humorously combining it with "Adiós" (meaning "Goodbye"). The speaker invents a nonsensical hybrid phrase, "adiós-ta la vista," which sounds funny because it's a playful misinterpretation of Spanish expressions. It's a lighthearted way of mixing up two common farewell phrases.
candidate: A person asks how to say 'goodbye' in Spanish and is told it's 'adios.' They then respond with a playful expression, saying 'okay, adios-ta la vista!' which is an informal way of saying farewell.

text: Una mujer siempre debe tener en su cartera una foto de su esposo, para que cuando tenga un mal día la mira, respire profundo y diga: "Si puedo con este, ¡puedo con todo!"
reference: The humor lies in the playful jab at the husband. The joke suggests that dealing with her husband is such a challenging task that it prepares the woman to face any other difficulty in life. It’s a lighthearted way of poking fun at the sometimes exasperating nature of relationships.
candidate: To always carry a photo of your husband in your purse, and when you have a bad day, look at it, take a deep breath, and say: 'If I can handle this, I can handle anything!' This empowering message highlights the importance of self-reminder and positive reinforcement, especially during tough times. The narrator emphasizes the value of having a visual reminder that serves as a motivating force to overcome challenges.

text: Si quieres tener el abdomen plano, píntate el ombligo en la espalda. Síganme para más consejos fitness.
reference: The humor comes from the absurdity of the "fitness tip," which is clearly not a real solution for achieving a flat stomach. Instead, it jokingly suggests an impossible and ridiculous action, painting your belly button on your back, to create the illusion of a flat abdomen. The punchline is enhanced by the sarcastic invitation to follow for more "fitness tips," mocking the abundance of unrealistic advice often found online.
candidate: To have a flat stomach, paint your belly button on your back. Follow me for more fitness tips.

text: Dioos, dame ganas de entrenar porque, con las de comer te estás pasando.
reference: The humor lies in the playful complaint directed at God, asking for motivation to exercise while humorously blaming Him for the excessive appetite. It's a relatable joke for many who struggle with balancing eating and working out, using exaggerated language to highlight the disparity between the two desires. The exaggerated tone adds a funny and lighthearted touch to the common dilemma.
candidate: It seems that Daioo wants to train now, because with every bite she devours, you're having too much fun.

text: Si alguien perdió sus sentimientos, favor de contactarse conmigo. Yo tengo sentimientos encontrados... Jajajajajajaj
reference: The humor comes from a play on words. The phrase "sentimientos encontrados" (mixed feelings) is a common expression to describe emotional conflict, but the joke takes it literally, as if the speaker has "found" someone else's lost feelings. The absurdity of this literal interpretation, combined with the exaggerated tone, makes it funny.
candidate: If someone lost their feelings, please reach out to me. I have mixed emotions... Ha ha ha

text: Los mexicanos podemos comer hasta 15 tacos en la noche, pero sandía NO, porque cae pesada.
reference: The humor lies in the absurd contradiction. Eating 15 tacos at night is clearly a heavy meal, yet the speaker humorously claims that watermelon, which is light and refreshing, is too "heavy" to eat at night. This exaggeration highlights cultural quirks and dietary habits in a playful way.
candidate: Mexicans can eat up to 15 tacos at night, but cantaloupe no, because it's too heavy.

text: Nunca hagamos sospechar a una mujer, porque cuando investiga una cosa, descubre 20 más. Es un don que les dio el diablo.
reference: The humor plays on the stereotype of women being exceptionally skilled at uncovering hidden truths or secrets. The exaggeration that they can find "20 more" things while investigating one adds a playful, hyperbolic twist.
